Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on Facebook posts and a purported legal order, which are not reliable sources of information.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the purported legal order is genuine and reflects the decision of an Indian court, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no Maharashtra High Court in India, and the only high court in Maharashtra is the Bombay High Court.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the impact of the game by stating that it is creating a lot of nuisance and spoiling the lives of many students, without providing substantial evidence to support this statement.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by using grammatically incorrect language and misspelled words, which would not be found in an official legal document.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation could be that the purported legal order is fake or fabricated, as there is no judge by the name of K. Srinivasulu at the Bombay High Court and the term "prejudge" is not an official job title in Indian legal lexicon.
Understate: The claim may understate the availability of the game in India, as it mentions that the mobile version of PUBG is available for download in India through Apple's app store.
